xokenzo: Loved loved loved this one. It had me pondering in traffic earlier today. I don't know you but if I were you I would be pretty darn proud of myself.
emilydhawkins: So grateful for this piece. I’ve worked diligently to become more comfortable with my appearance without so much effort and additions and this has been inspiring.
des_at_play: I stopped wearing makeup my freshman year of college and it was surprising how negative some people were towards me because of it. Guys would call me ice queen and a girl once told a guy I was seeing that I must not like him very much because I wouldn’t put in the effort. I learned that when women are literally comfortable in their own skin, people can find that threatening because we’re all so programmed to believe women should hate how they look and be insecure and working tirelessly to get others’ approval.
nomakeupnofember: We LOVE your article! Would you consider sending this lovely photo to our Facebook page? (Link in bio). We have a Facebook album celebrating make-up-free faces while simultaneously raising $ for girls' education in Africa! It's all about shaking up the status quo for a good cause! No pressure to donate. We would love to include you in the album either way! ❤️
agnfnk: You look awesome without makeup! I mean.. we all look great as we are. Both - women and men. I could not be bothered putting makeup on every morning. Not only because it's a waste of time, but it would change me, my "real" face. Plus.. you have to fix it during the day. Fuck that. If I need to "fix" something - it would be refreshing my pyssy with a wet napkin. 😙
_bobandrews_: I’ve read this article at least 5 times over the last few days, and each time it sinks in further. I’ve never been able to so eloquently and impactfully articulate this exact sentiment, but I guess that’s why we have humans like you on this planet. Thank you for writing what I have been feeling.
maur.velous: Ahhh I did the no makeup project for a year! This relates so much. @makeuplessmaura
elisego7: that self-assessment/analysis is incredibly interesting to me.
whatsusaw: Good to know sooner rather than not. BC time. US society considers elders, especially XX, invisible. #whatweknownow
mansinegi_: Really, really liked reading this. More power. x
gaskell_jewelry: Yes.. when we rid ourselves from those rituals our true beauty emerges ❤️
clare_l_baker: You’re a talented and beautiful girl. Love this story 👏🏼
batiagabriellephotography: It's a beautiful thing you are saying, even though I can't relate. stinevincent: I really liked and relate to your piece! I rarely wear makeup but I do feel the obligation for events and when I want to "look pretty," or just professional. You've inspired me to challenge that impulse more.
melaniemachamer: appreciate the inside of your brain, very much, thank you. A friend told me he told his 4yr old daughter (who was obsessed w. looking in the mirror) “there’s nothing good in that mirror because it’s just a visual reflection. leilaa_anne: Love this! Powerful words. You’re beautiful
katia.leo.nova: I feel beautyful without makeup but I love it so much that I can't go makeup free, I love it not for masking me but for the statement I can make with it now.
lauraquicenosoto: . When I finally started to let it go, I saw, for the first time, a path to better understanding myself. And embracing my own vastness.
kirsten: Not only do I love and relate to this message, but I really appreciate that you recognize your privilege in terms of western beauty standards and respect others journeys. You didn’t tell anyone what to do, you just asked us to consider something most of us never have because it’s so indoctrinated in women. In a world of black and white, yes or no, right or wrong, this type of measured self reflection and open dialogue is what we could all use more of.
htxtra: Love and appreciate this so much!!! I never really enjoyed wearing makeup, but began to feel like I should at least try it out to see if I would like it. Surprise, I still don't, at least not enough to put the time in more than occasionally. But now, after coming back to that same conclusion, I have a full makeup bag of things I don't really need and a few hundred dollars less in my bank account to show for it. It hurts a bit to know that the beauty-industrial complex successfully took me in for a little while, but I sincerely enjoy and am thankful for the solidarity in shrugging it off once again with you.
gigilhall: If I had eyebrows, I’d be able to give up makeup
carmellarm: I have always thought this, thank you for sharing with the world! I think you can compare it to how men dont wear makeup or go to the same extent of drastically altering their appearances, but we still find them attractive! While part of that is the lower expectation of beauty standards we hold for men, I think part of it is because we are used to their regular bare faces! It's crazy that the notion of normalizing our own faces is a thing, but it's definitely a thing we should work on, it's part of being comfortable in our own skin and breaking down beauty standards✨
violagreyofficial: This is beautiful, thanks for being wonderful and open.
bronsonalexandra: Like if you want plastic surgery do it if you don’t want to shave your mustache don’t shave it
pbehnken: Amazing and inspiring. Thanks for this beautiful story.
thelollasite: That’s so weird to read. I find you so pretty, and very sweet 🖤🖤🖤
samantharhiannonwilliams: My first reaction to this post (which I loved BTW) was 'yes but she'd beautiful which makes it ok for her, I could never go makeup free because I look like a ginger egg.' aletraeffe: I bet you know you are so much prettier now! I can't help being a big fan of you and everything you write. 🤓😍
agostinaillu: I loved reading this!!! I am 99.9 makeup free except for weddings where i also take the opportunity to brush my hair lol😂
mariah_wettberg: I think you a beautiful. I always wanted your bangs but cowardly decline every time I make an attempt at the hairdressers.
ines_sercelj: You are so freaking beautiful inside and out and I love you for what you’ve written! Amazing. Thank you ❤️
shirel.cb: No makeup rules! Love this essay👏

snakejuicee: I think the most beautiful part about you is your kind gaze and welcoming smile 😊 it's what drew me to you.
street_style_bristol: This is such a wonderful quote, and one I relate to very deeply ❤️❤️
joellegrace: You’re writing is incredible and inspiring and also I’d love to photograph you ❤️
steficulafic: Do you know that you are the best
daria.eiche: That’s my goal, to be makeup-free at all times
elloau: This is beautifully straightforward 🙌 And also, FUCK makeup 🖕
fraiznic: I’ve always used very few make up - probably because my mum doesn’t use any make up at all. As a teenager I was a bit jelaous of my friends ability to appear shiny and perfect at parties, yet trying to imitate them always felt like putting a mask on my face. As you say, looking exactly the same when I wake up in the morning and when I shower before bed is something that makes me happy: I recognize myself in the mirror and that’s the most important thing ✨ Your stories are always illuminating 😘
aileux: This is something I resonate with deeply. I gave up make up a couple of years ago and noticed the same difference but didn’t know how to put it into words. Thank you for your eloquence as always!
lizjac: "...my attention rerouted to somewhere more interesting..." This part, to me, is important. How much energy we women waste on these sorts of things makes me feel sick sometimes. Imagine what we could accomplish if we used that energy for other ends.
jacquidevaney: Needed this 🙏🏻 today’s my first day sans foundation in many, many months
girl.named.shadow: Just read the article and want to thank you for writing it. I still struggle and cling to mascara, but like your acne, my year long fight with rosacea made me quit foundations and let my skin breathe. I also quit coloring my hair or trying to get tan. I don't turn heads, but I feel more like me. Not to mention have more time to do things I actually like doing. It's about ❤️❤️❤️
likeoneofyourfrenchgirls: The w mag article forever 21 really opened my eyes to the real price tag of beauty. If you don't have 30gs a year to spend on your looks then you have to be OK with looking older. It's tough when girls our age all have preventive botox and lip fillers, I feel the only option is just to just spend less time looking at ourselves in the mirror or go crazy
jessutherland: Wow this has resonated with me in such a big way... thank you for sharing 😊
zsooofizsooofi: I stopped wearing makeup around 6 months ago. It’s such a liberating feeling, not just because I used to believe I don’t look good enough bare faced, but also because my shopping routines have simplified: less shops to walk in to, less products to purchase/try/get rid of. It feels truly life changing.
rach_ehl: Thank you for dishing the older sister advice I never had! 👏
garbage_lewks: @alliebeth.c This reminds me of things you’ve said.
outrastudio: I was completely off wearing makeup a few years ago during a period of 'beauty' rebellion. While not wearing makeup and having body hair were such subtle differences in my appearance, these decisions felt weirdly radical. Especially with the body hair - it clearly repulsed some strangers which mostly just left me feeling mad - why do people care so much that women follow all of these same weird rules and how are they so offended when we choose not to? Then I shaved my head which turned out to be a step too far for me. While I wholeheartedly feel these norms are oppressive, it can be really hard sometimes to not play along. But I love you and your writing and so appreciate this article <3
melissasuehernandez: I love this so much. I’m with you! ❤️
channitychanchan: I loved this article. Thank you for sharing 🙂
kneesinwater: I loved this piece. You put words to so many disconnected thoughts that have been floating around my head for the last couple of years: the western cultural idea that our bodies are imperfect and that to choose anything less than a lifelong all-out effort to *be better* is largely unacceptable. To do so is to “let yourself go” with negative connotations ... which when you think about it, letting oneself “go” seems pretty freaking liberating and way more fun.
flausinas_: @halemur Enjoying following you more and more xxx👏🙌
harriet_md: I rarely wear makeup - once a month tops. Always miserable when I do, plus I over think and fuss! I’ve thought for a while that maybe it’s not other people that treat us differently depending on whether we’re wearing makeup or not- but rather women are taught to treat ourselves as not worthy of certain occasions and attention if not made up 🤷🏻‍♀️
twillesen: 🙌🏼 I’ve been without makeup for three years now and love it! Guess it’s more the norm here in Copenhagen where I live compared to the States. Thanks for bringing up this important subject.
pagoots: I haven’t worn make up, regularly, for several years now, and I look forward to reading this! I still enjoy a lip from time to time and pretending I’ll wear eye make up more frequently, but the importance around it just doesn’t have space in my life routine. I save it for special occasions and I love how a little can make you feel that extra something... though I am still always amazed at the comments I get when I DO wear it.
aherm1226: Wow this was a wonderful piece. Thank you ❤️
laradigar: Can’t wait to get home and read this!!! Very interesting subject and eager to hear what you have to say about it ☺️
self.righteousbabe: I *mostly* gave up makeup almost two years ago and my 33 year old face has never been happier. Thank you for sharing!
milkbean: Natural beauty really blossoms from honest inner beauty and you got it girl.
tiggington: I think about all this stuff a lot, but I’ve never thought about it in quite the way you describe - the static quality as a natural consequence of not constantly changing / hiding oneself aesthetically, and how that leaves space for more interesting things to take ones attention. samantha.r.martin: I love this! I stopped wearing makeup a few years ago and not only is my skin happier but I like my face more. I like knowing what I look like. I still really enjoy doing my makeup for special occasions and have recently dipped my toe back into the lipstick + a swipe of mascara LEWK pond, but otherwise its such a relief to just let your face be your face. This is obviously a personal choice and women who love wearing makeup everyday (for themselves) are just as great as those who don't!
dianalatigra: 🤣 I love that you quoted yourself. More of that needs to happen. We have wisdom inside we might as well own it and share it.
